messageBody:
On 10/3/06, Uma Maheswara.G <gunipati81@...> wrote:
> Hi Guys,
>
> I have joined Junit Groups recently and i am working on Junit test cases.
> Could please tell me the coding standards for JUNIT Testing.

Ahhh, an interesting question. Thank you for caring about such things.

There are no coding standards for JUnit users. There are various
community agreed best practices, but I'm not sure if they're written
down anywhere. The first place that I'd look would be the JUnit FAQ.
As I look at it, it does have a section titled best practices.

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm

The next thing I'd do would be to use a search engine, we like Google
around here, and I'd search on keywords such as "JUnit best practices"
or some such similar thing and see what you get.

The third thing that I'd do would be to start cranking out test cases.
There is no teacher better than experience and in truth, that's how
many of us learned to use JUnit (rumour has it that J.B. was born
already knowing the deeper secrets of JUnit and that the text of JUnit
Recipes is encoded in his DNA).

A great place to start with writing JUnit tests is the Java API. Pick
an object, String is a good candidate, and start writing tests for it.
You will amaze yourself with how quickly you'll get the hang of
writing tests by even such a simple exercise. It'll also help your
understanding of the String class, and that's a good thing too.

Simon
